summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence between U.S. prosecutors and other officials, primarily concerning the preparation and logistics of an MLAT (Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty) request to France related to the investigation of Jean-Luc Brunel. The emails discuss search term strategies for document review, scheduling meetings, and note that an attorney for victims has declined interviews with French authorities.

connections.description: Mg is identified as the attorney representing adult victims who have described instances of abuse by Epstein in Paris.

events.title: Victims' Attorney Declines French Interviews
events.description: The attorney for victims (Mg) emails U.S. officials to indicate her clients do not wish to be interviewed by French authorities and provides her contact information for direct liaison.

events.title: Meeting on Brunel Investigation
events.description: A U.S. official reports that a meeting regarding Jean-Luc Brunel went well and provides a readout to colleagues.

events.title: Search Term Results Provided
events.description: Officials provide a chart reflecting search terms run in Relativity and the number of results for each term, as part of document review for the case.

keyFacts: The correspondence is focused on preparing an MLAT request to France related to the investigation of Jean-Luc Brunel.
An attorney (Mg) representing adult victims of Epstein in Paris informed U.S. authorities that her clients do not wish to be interviewed by French authorities.
Officials are coordinating search term strategies in Relativity for document review, discussing the volume of results and the need for specific, focused requests.
The emails show ongoing coordination between U.S. prosecutors and other officials in early 2021 regarding international evidence gathering.
